The measurement is taken at ten specific points on both the main and intermediate transects of the stream. These points are located at 5%, 15%, 25%, 35%, 45%, 55%, 65%, 75%, 85%, and 95% from one scour line to the opposite scour line. This method is necessary for understanding the distribution of particle sizes in a streambed, which can provide valuable information about the stream's sediment dynamics and its ability to support aquatic life. By measuring at multiple locations and comparing the results, researchers or scientists can identify any trends or changes in particle size distribution across the streambed.
